ui.fallbackSummary: Start with the last line of the message and the highlighted code line.
ui.fallbackWhy: The last line of the traceback tells you the error type and main cause.
ui.fallbackStep: Fix one small thing and run again.

variants.title: This name doesn't exist yet
variants.summary: Your code uses "{{name}}", but it hasn't been created yet. Check {{loc}}. If you meant the text {{name}}, put it in double quotes.
variants.why: Python needs to see a line that creates "{{name}}" before you use it.
steps: Make it first (for example: {{name}} = 0).
Check spelling and capital letters.

variants.title: This name doesn't exist here
variants.summary: "{{name}}" might be created somewhere else, but you're using it at {{loc}}. If you meant the text {{name}}, put it in double quotes.
variants.why: A name created in another place might not be available here.
steps: Move the line that makes it to above where you use it.
Or set it here just before you use it.

variants.title: Used before it gets a value in this part of the code
variants.summary: Here, "{{name}}" is used at {{loc}} before you give it a value.
variants.why: Because you assign to this name in this part, Python treats it as local here. It is read before you set it.
steps: Give it a value first (add a line like {{name}} = ... before you use it).
If you meant a different value, use a different name here.

variants.title: Missing colon (:) at the end
variants.summary: This line starts a block and needs a colon at {{loc}}: {{codeLine}}
variants.why: In Python, lines that start a block must end with a colon.
steps: Add a colon (:) at the end of that line.

variants.title: The line is incomplete or mismatched
variants.summary: Something is missing or extra â€” like a colon, bracket, or quote.
variants.why: If (), [], {}, :, or quotes don't match, Python can't read the line.
steps: Make (), [], and {} come in matching pairs.
Add the missing colon (:).
Use matching opening and closing quotes.

variants.title: The indentation doesn't match
variants.summary: All lines in a block must start in the same column. Fix around {{loc}}.
variants.why: Python groups code by indentation. Mixing tabs and spaces or uneven indents breaks the block.
steps: Use 4 spaces per level (not tabs).
Line up all lines in the block.

variants.title: These values don't work together
variants.summary: You're combining different kinds of values (for example, a number and a word).
variants.why: Operators like + only work with certain kinds together.
steps: Change a value to the right kind: int("3") or str(7).
Use an operator that works with these values.

variants.title: Lists don't have that feature
variants.summary: You're calling a list method that doesn't exist.
variants.why: Lists use .append(value) or .extend([...]). There is no .push().
steps: Use list.append(one_item).
Use list.extend([many, items]).

variants.title: This thing doesn't have that name after the dot
variants.summary: The thing you're using doesn't have that attribute or method.
variants.why: That kind of thing doesn't provide this feature.
steps: Check the spelling after the dot.
Use a name that exists for this kind of thing.

variants.title: That position is outside the list
variants.summary: You're asking for a list position that isn't there.
variants.why: List positions start at 0 and stop before the list's length.
steps: Check the length with len(the_list).
Use a position number smaller than len(the_list).

variants.title: That key isn't in the dictionary
variants.summary: You looked up a key that the dictionary doesn't have.
variants.why: The dictionary has no value for that key.
steps: Check the exact key (spelling and capital letters).
If it might be missing, use dictionary.get(key, default) or add the key first.
